--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> Indeed. More generally though right now I'm trying to clarify in my
head 
> whether a complex development stage has any benefits over and above 
> systems like my own (with some kind indirect encoding)- or whether
the 
> development phase seen in biology is purely a necessity of existing
and 
> trying to grow in the real, physical world with limited resources
to 
> hand. Having said that any system with indirect encoding has to go

Definitely that is the big question.  What aspects of biological
development are computationally efficient and what aspects are
necessitated by physics?  That's one reason I wrote the Taxonomy
paper, to point out that no one has sorted this out yet.  There are
several properties of biological development that we really need to
implement with experiments to see how they contribute to evolvability.
It is almost certain, though, that some of these properties are
crucial, such as canalization (as you say below).
 
> At the same time I can see that a more indirect encoding might
possibly 
> support robustness in a genome encoding (canalization). This is
were 
> things get difficult, certainly the relative positioning in my own 
> system gives us some sort of canalization as does my connection
strategy 
> (connect to the neuron closest to the end of the connection), but
these 
> are quite simple techniques and trying to envisage how greater
levels of 
> indirection would be beneficial is difficult.
> 

Yes I agree that your technique, particularly the closest-connection
rule, provides some kind of canalization.
(Cangelosi et al. implemented a similar rule)  But one thing
that I've been talking about with people at UT is the connection
between canalization and self-organization.  That is, a system
that is canalized needs to be ability to self-organize, since 
otherwise it is brittle.  And self-organization would seem to require
some kind of signaling among parts.  So signaling might be key.

> 
> For now I'm interested in implementing speciation and seeing what
sort 
> of impact it has. As in crossover I intend to compare the tree 
> structures in order to generate a compatibility number with which
to 
> drive the speciation. This then should create a system very much
like 
> NEAT but with the ability to complexify - that's the theory anyhow
:-)
> 

That sounds like it will be quite interesting.  But when you said,
"NEAT but with the ability to complexify," did you mean "but without
the ability to complexify?"  I'm not clear how complexification enters
into your system?

Also, are you putting in some kind of historical marking system?  If
not, how can you implement accurate speciation?  Similar looking trees
can have quite different meanings,can't they?

ken
